fr:mainmatter.html:p: We say a property of distributive lattices is stalk local, if for any A, A satisfies P iff for all x\in \operatorname {Spec} A in the prime spectrum, A/x satisfies P.

Let X be an arbitrary scheme. Let P be a property of affine opens of X. We say P is affine local, if
for any \operatorname {Spec} A satisfying P, so is \operatorname {Spec} A/a \subseteq \operatorname {Spec} A for any a\in A.
if there exists finitely many a_i of A with \bigvee _{i}a_i = 1 where each \operatorname {Spec} A_i satisfies P, then the union \operatorname {Spec} A = \bigcup _{i}\operatorname {Spec} A_i also satisfies P.

Let X be a scheme and let P be an affine local property on X. If there exists an affine open cover \{\operatorname {Spec} A_i\}_{i\in I} of X with each \operatorname {Spec} A_i satisfying P, then any affine open of X satisfies P.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose we have an arbitrary affine open \operatorname {Spec} D of X. Since \operatorname {Spec} D is quasi-compact, we can cover \operatorname {Spec} D by finitely many \operatorname {Spec} A_i with each \operatorname {Spec} A_i satisfying P. Since standard opens of \operatorname {Spec} D form a basis, we can choose a generating family \{d_j\}_{j\in J} in D with \bigvee _{j\in J}d_j = 1, and each \operatorname {Spec} D/d_j is contained in some \operatorname {Spec} A_i. But since \operatorname {Spec} D/d_j is open compact in \operatorname {Spec} A_i, it can be identified as some \operatorname {Spec} A_i/a_j for some a_j in A_i. By assumption of P being affine local, each \operatorname {Spec} D/d_i satisfies P, hence \operatorname {Spec} D satisfies P.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The affine commutation lemma has a wide range of applications, because we can view properties of morphisms of schemes and sheaves on schemes as affine local properties:

Let P be a property of morphisms of schemes. Then we say P is affine local on the target, if for any f : Y \to X, the property on affine opens \operatorname {Spec} A of X where the restriction f^{-1}(\operatorname {Spec} A) \to \operatorname {Spec} A satisfies P is affine local.

Let P be a property of sheaves on X. Then we say P is affine local, if for any sheaf \mathcal {F} on X, the property on affine opens \operatorname {Spec} A of X where the restriction \mathcal {F}_{\operatorname {Spec} A} satisfies P is affine local.
A stronger local condition is stalk local:
We say a property of distributive lattices is stalk local, if for any A, A satisfies P iff for all x\in \operatorname {Spec} A in the prime spectrum, A/x satisfies P.
If P is a stalk local property, then for any scheme X, the property of affine open \operatorname {Spec} A with A satisfying P is affine local.

We say a scheme is quasi-separated if its underlying topological space is quasi-separated. We say it is quasi-compact if its underlying space is compact. The two conditions are often combined together and written as qcqs.
More generally, we say a morphism f : Y \to X of schemes is quasi-compact, if the underlying continuous map is quasi-compact.

fr:title.text: A quasi-separated but not quasi-compact scheme

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A quasi-separated but not quasi-compact scheme

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Note the scheme \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+ from Example is quasi-separated but not quasi-compact.

fr:title.text: Quasi-compact and quasi-separated are affine local

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quasi-compact and quasi-separated are affine local

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Both quasi-compact and quasi-separated are trivially affine local properties because all affine schemes are qcqs.
We say a scheme is irreducible if its underlying topological space is irreducible.

fr:title.text: Irreducible affine schemes have integral global section

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible affine schemes have integral global section

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For an affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} A, it is irreducible iff A is integral.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since \operatorname {Spec} D is sober by Theorem , it is irreducible iff it has a generic point, i.e. iff D has a unique maximal filter. This holds iff D is integral by the dual statement of Proposition .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices are always irreducible, since free distributive lattices are always integral.
On the other hand, Boolean algebras, except 2, are all not integral, hence their affine schemes are never irreducible --- in fact, since they are Stone spaces, they are totally disconnected.

In contrast, there exist non-initial integral Heyting algebras (e.g. non-trivial linear Heyting algebras are integral). However, free Heyting algebras, except 2, are not integral, but they will be local. For instance, the spectrum \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x] in Example has two irreducible components, corresponding to the two maximal points.

Dually, free coHeyting algebras will be integral. For instance, the dual Rieger-Nishimura scheme \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {S}[x] is irreducible. This can be also directly seen since it has a generic point.
In fact, the statement in Lemma can be made stronger.
A scheme X is integral, if it is non-empty, and for every non-empty open U of X, \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) is integral.
If X is an integral scheme, then for any x\in X, the stalk \mathcal {O}_{X,x} will be integral. This is because integral distributive lattices are closed under filtered colimits.

However, the converse is not true though. The simplest counterexample is the affine scheme 2 on the discrete space. It has integral schemes, since both stalks are the initial distributive lattice 2, which are integral. But this affine scheme fails to be integral since its global section is 2 \times 2 \cong \mathbb {B}[x], which is not integral. Hence, being integral is not an affine local property.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of integral distributive lattices are integral

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of integral distributive lattices are integral

fr:mainmatter.html:p: D is integral iff \operatorname {Spec} D is integral.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose D is integral. By Proposition an arbitrary open subset corresponds to an ideal I. Recall from Proposition , the value \mathcal {O}_{D}(O_I) is D_I, the lattice of I-elements of D. Let u,v\in D_I with u \wedge v = 0. This means that for all i\in I, u(i) \wedge v(i) = 0. We show if u(i) \neq 0 for some i\in I, then v = 0. For any j\in I, we have v(j) \wedge u(i) \le j \wedge u(i) = u(i \wedge j). Similarly, v(j) \wedge u(i) \le v(j) \wedge i = v(i\wedge j), which implies that v(j) \wedge u(i) \le u(i \wedge j) \wedge v(i \wedge j) = (u \wedge v)(i \wedge j) = 0. Hence, since D is integral and u(i) \neq 0, we must have v(j) = 0, for all j\in I. This proves D_I is also integral.

fr:title.text: Structural sheaves of integral affine schemes have f-conservative transition maps

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Structural sheaves of integral affine schemes have f-conservative transition maps

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For an integral affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} D, for two non-trivial ideals J \subseteq I, the restriction map (cf. Proposition ) D_I \to D_J is f-conservative.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since J is non-trivial, pick some j\in J with j\neq 0. Now suppose u|_{O_J} = 0 for some u\in D_I. This way, for any i\in I we have u(i) \wedge j = u(i \wedge j) = 0. By D being integral, it means u(i) = 0, thus u = 0 in D_I.

fr:title.text: A scheme is integral iff it is irreducible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A scheme is integral iff it is irreducible

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A scheme X is integral iff it is irreducible.

For \Leftarrow , if X is not irreducible, then we can find two non-empty but disjoint opens U,V. This way, \mathcal {O}_{X}(U \cup V) \cong \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \times \mathcal {O}_{X}(V), which is not integral.

For \Rightarrow , if X is irreducible then so is any affine open, and by Lemma they are all integral. For any open U, to show \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) is integral, we pick a non-empty affine open V\subseteq U. The restriction map \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \to \mathcal {O}_{X}(V) is f-conservative by Lemma . Suppose we have a\in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) with a|_V = 0. For any affine open W \subseteq U, we know the image of a|_W in W \cap V is 0, By , a|_W must also be 0. This shows a = 0 in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U).
We say a scheme X is locally Noetherian, if it can be covered by affine subspaces \operatorname {Spec} A_i with each A_i Noetherian. We say X is Noetherian if it is furthermore quasi-compact.
By definition, an affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} A is Noetherian iff A is Noetherian.

From Example , \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x] is not Noetherian, since \mathbb {H}[x] has infinite ascending elements. In fact, it is not locally Noetherian either, due to the existance of the focal point \bot of \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x], whose only open neighbourhood is the entire space. However, the open subscheme \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+ of \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x] described in Example is locally Noetherian.
Dually, from Example we know \mathbb {S}[x] is Noetherian, hence \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {S}[x] is Noetherian.
Being Noetherian is an affine local property.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since Noetherian distributive lattices are closed under quotients, the first condition of affine local is trivial. Now suppose we have \bigvee _{i\in I}a_i = 1 with each A/a_i Noetherian. Any finite ascending sequence in A induces inifinite ascending sequences in A_i, which must be stationary by assumption. Since the family \{A_i\}_{i\in I} is finite, they must have a common upper bound where all sequences being stationary. This implies the original sequence must be stationary, hence A is Noetherian.

fr:title.text: Noetherian schemes have Noetherian underlying topological spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Noetherian schemes have Noetherian underlying topological spaces

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If X is a Noetherian scheme, then its underlying topological space is Noetherian.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It suffices to observe that A is a Noetherian distributive lattice iff \operatorname {Spec} A is a Noetherian topological space. This holds by Proposition that closed subsets of \operatorname {Spec} A are dually isomorphic to ideals of A. Then it suffices to observe a finite union of Noetherian topological spaces is again Noetherian.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A locally Noetherian scheme is quasi-separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By Lemma and affine commutation, if X is locally Noetherian, then any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A is Noetherian. In particular, the intersection \operatorname {Spec} A \cap \operatorname {Spec} B for two affine open is quasi-compact by Lemma .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The property of an affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of X that A is a Heyting algebra or a Boolean algebra is affine local.
Evidently if A is a Heyting algebra then so is A/a for any a\in A.

Now suppose we have \bigvee _{i\in I}a_i = 1 with each A_i := A/a_i a Heyting algebra. We will write abbreviate the localisation A \twoheadrightarrow A/a_i simply as (-)_i := a_i \wedge (-). For any x,y \in A, we define x \to y := \bigvee _{i\in I} x_i \to _i y_i, where \to _i is the Heyting implication in A_i. This is evidently monotone on y. Hence, to show x \to (-) is the right adjoint of x \wedge -, it suffices to give the unit and counit.

For the unit, it requires y \le x \to (x \wedge y). By construction, using the unit for each \to _i, we have
\begin {align*} y &= \bigvee _{i\in I} y_i \\ &\le \bigvee _{i\in I} x_i \to _i (x_i \wedge y_i) \\ &= x \to (x \wedge y) \end {align*}
The case for Boolean algebras is trivial.

We say a scheme X is Heyting/Boolean if there is an affine open cover \{\operatorname {Spec} A_i\}_{i\in I} of X where each A_i is Heyting/Boolean. Equivalently by Lemma , this means all affine open of X will be Heyting/Boolean.
A scheme X is Heyting/Boolean iff \mathcal {O}_{X} is internally a Heyting/Boolean algebra.

On the other hand, if X is Heyting, then for any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A there is a Heyting implication (-) \to _A (-) : \mathcal {O}_{X}(\operatorname {Spec} A)^{\mathrm {op}} \times \mathcal {O}_{X}(\operatorname {Spec} A) \cong A^{\mathrm {op}} \times A \to A \cong \mathcal {O}_{X}(\operatorname {Spec} A) Furthermore, they must agree on intersections because the implication is uniquely determined. This way all the local implications glue together to provide an implication for \mathcal {O}_{X}, and it will be the internal Heyting implication by the Kripke-Joyal semantics.

fr:title.text: Can being Heyting checked on stalks?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Can being Heyting checked on stalks?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We know from Lemma that being Heyting is affine local. Furthermore, if X is a Heyting scheme, then evidently for any x\in X, the stalk \mathcal {O}_{X,x} is a local Heyting algebra. However, is the converse true, i.e. is being Heyting a stalk local property?

The related question for Boolean algebras is positive, since being Boolean is geometric, i.e. for a sheaf of distributive lattice \mathcal {O}_{X} over X, it is Boolean iff it satisfies the following geometric sequent, \top \vdash _{x\in \mathcal {O}_{X}} \exists y \in \mathcal {O}_{X}.\ (x \wedge y = 0) \wedge (x \vee y = 1) However, it seems to be quite hard to come up with a geometric description of being Heyting. This ultimately reduces to an algebraic problem.
If P is a stalk local property, then for any scheme X, the property of affine open \operatorname {Spec} A with A satisfying P is affine local.

fr:title.text: Prime spectrum of a distributive lattice

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of a distributive lattice

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any distributive lattice D, we use \operatorname {Spec} D to denote the poset of prime filters of D. Equivalently, this is the poset of models of D.
